intro: Phlox douglasii var. modocensis, commonly known as Modoc phlox, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of showy, fragrant flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or open habitats. Its foliage consists of narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, white powdery coating.
